The meek —The word ‘meek’ usually refers to those who are patient in the reception of injuries, but the Hebrew word used here (ענוים ‛ănâviym) means properly the oppressed, the afflicted, the unhappyPsalm 9:13; Psalm 10:12, Psalm 10:17; Proverbs 3:34 ;Isaiah 11:4 . It involves usually the idea of humility or “virtuous suffering” (comparePsalm 25:9; Psalm 37:11; Psalm 69:33). Here it may denote the pious of the land who were oppressed, and subjected to trials.

Shall increase —Margin, as in Hebrew, ‘Add.’ It means, that they should greatly rejoice in the Lord. They should see the evidence of the fulfillment of his predictions; they should see the oppressors punishedIsaiah 29:20-21 , and Yahweh coming forth to be their protector and defenderIsaiah 29:22-24 .

And the poor among men —The poor people; or the needy. Doubtless the idea is that of the pious poor; those who feared God, and who had been subjected to the trials of oppression and poverty.
